nickelAlloys.name: Hastelloy C-22
nickelAlloys.description:
Hastelloy C-22 is a nickel-molybdenum-chromium-tungsten alloy with excellent general corrosion resistance and good fabricability.The alloy should be considered for use in environments where resistance to hot contaminated mineral acids, organic and inorganic chloride-contaminated media, chlorine, formic and acetic acids, acetic, acetic anhydride, sea water and brine solutions is desired.Hastelloy C-22 has resisted the formation of grain boundary precipitates in the weld heat-affected zone, making it a candidate for most chemical and petrochemical processing applications in the as-welded condition. The alloy has resisted both general and localized corrosion, including pitting, crevice corrosion, and stress corrosion cracking.
Hastelloy C-22 is readily fabricated by welding, using methods similar to those utilized for nickel-based alloys.
nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Hastelloy C-22 is a versatile nickel-chromium-molybdenum alloy with better overall corrosion resistance than other Ni-Cr-Mo alloys available today, including Hastelloy C-276, C-4, and Alloy 625. Alloy C-22 has outstanding resistance to pitting, crevice corrosion, and stress-corrosion cracking. It has excellent resistance to oxidizing aqueous media, including acids with oxidizing agents, wet chlorine, and mixtures containing nitric acid or oxidizing acids with chlorine ions. Hastelloy C-22 has outstanding resistance to both reducing and oxidizing media, and because of its versatility, it can be used where 'upset' conditions are likely to occur or in multipurpose plants. Hastelloy C-22 has exceptional resistance to a wide variety of chemical process environments, including strong oxidizers such as ferric and cupric chlorides, hot contaminated media (organic and inorganic), chlorine, formic and acetic acids, acetic anhydride, and seawater and brine solutions. Hastelloy C-22 resists the formation of grain boundary precipitates in the weld heat-affected zone, thus making it suitable for most chemical process applications in the as-welded condition.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hastelloy C-22 can be fabricated using the same techniques as are used for alloys C-276 or C-4. It can be welded, forged, hot-upset, and impact extruded. Alloy C-22 can also be successfully deep-drawn, spun, press-formed, or punched, although the alloy tends to work-harden. Parts which have been hot formed or severely cold formed should be heat treated at 2050 °F and rapidly quenched prior to final fabrication or installation.
nickelAlloys.applications: Some of the areas of present or potential use for Alloy C-22 are: Acetic acid/Acetic Anhydride production, cellophane manufacturing, chlorine spargers, chlorination systems, circuit board etching equipment, complex acid/chemical mixtures, fans and blowers, galvanizing line equipment, gas scrubber systems, geothermal wells, HF furnaces, incineration systems, nuclear fuel reprocessing, pesticide production, phosphoric acid applications, pickling system components, plate heat exchangers, selective leaching systems, sulfur oxide cooling towers, sulfonation systems, and tubular heat exchangers.

sizesAvailable.Pipes: ¼”NB to 8”NB x SCH 10/40/80/160/XXS (Larger sizes available on request)
sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm Dia (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.name: Hastelloy C-276
nickelAlloys.description: Hastelloy C-276 is a nickel-molybdenum-chromium-tungsten alloy with excellent general corrosion resistance and good fabricability. It is suitable for use in environments involving hot contaminated mineral acids, chloride-contaminated media, chlorine, formic and acetic acids, acetic anhydride, sea water, and brine solutions. It resists grain boundary precipitates in weld heat-affected zones, allowing use in as-welded conditions.
nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Hastelloy C-276 is balanced to provide excellent corrosion resistance to a variety of chemical process environments. This alloy has provided resistance to hot contaminated mineral acids, organic and inorganic chloride-contaminated media, hypochlorite, chlorine dioxide solutions, formic and acetic acids, acetic anhydride, sea water, and brine solutions.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hastelloy C-276 can be forged, hot-upset, and impact extruded. Although the alloy tends to work-harden, it can be successfully deep-drawn, spun, press-formed, or punched. All common methods of welding can be used, though oxy-acetylene and submerged arc processes are not recommended for corrosion service.
nickelAlloys.welding: Gas tungsten-arc, gas metal-arc, shielded metal-arc, and resistance welding methods are usable. Minimum heat input is recommended to avoid hot cracking. Oxyacetylene welding should be avoided due to potential carburization.
nickelAlloys.heatTreatment: Typically solution heat-treated at 2050 °F and rapidly quenched. Hot-formed parts should undergo heat treatment before final fabrication or installation when possible.
nickelAlloys.applications: Used in chemical processing, pollution control, pulp and paper production, marine engineering, and waste treatment. It performs well in aggressive media.

nickelAlloys.name: Inconel 718
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 718 is a precipitation hardenable nickel-based alloy designed to display exceptionally high yield, tensile and creep-rupture properties at temperatures up to 1300°F. The sluggish age-hardening response of alloy 718 permits annealing and welding without spontaneous hardening during heating and cooling. This alloy has excellent weldability compared to nickel-base superalloys hardened by aluminum and titanium. It is used for jet engine and high-speed airframe parts such as wheels, buckets, spacers, and high-temperature bolts and fasteners.
nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Excellent resistance to a wide range of corrosive environments including oxidizing and reducing conditions.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hot-working is carried out using a 2050°F (1121°C) maximum furnace temperature. Hot-cold working in the range 1700/1850°F (927/1010°C) will improve the strength of the forging if the service temperature is below about 1100°F (593°C). Prolonged soaking at the forging temperature is not desirable. The material should be given uniform reductions to avoid the formation of duplex grain structures.
nickelAlloys.welding: Alloy 718 can be welded in both annealed and aged conditions. Welding in the aged condition will cause the formation of a softened heat-affected zone.
nickelAlloys.heatTreatment: The following heat treatment should be used to obtain the best combination of tensile properties and stress rupture properties: 1 hr 1750°F to 1800°F (954 to 982°C) air cool + 8hr 1325°F (718°C) cool 100°F/hr to 1150°F (56°C/hr to 621°C), hold 8 hrs and air cool. To obtain the best room temperature and cryogenic tensile properties: 1 to 2 hr 1950°F (1066°C), air cool + 8 hr 1325°F (718°C) cool 100°F/hr to 1150°F (56°C/hr to 621°C), hold 8 hr and air cool.
nickelAlloys.machining: The alloy can be readily machined in either the annealed or the age-hardened condition. The age-hardened condition gives better chip action on chip breaker tools and produces a better finish. The annealed condition will give a slightly longer tool life.

nickelAlloys.name: Inconel 600 / 601
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 600 is a nonmagnetic, nickel-based high temperature alloy possessing excellent strength, hot/cold workability, and resistance to ordinary forms of corrosion. Alloy 601 is a nickel-chromium alloy with added aluminum for superior oxidation and high-temperature corrosion resistance. It also maintains high mechanical properties at elevated temperatures.
nickelAlloys.application: Used in industrial furnaces, heat-treating equipment (baskets, muffles, retorts), petrochemical and process equipment, and gas-turbine components.

nickelAlloys.name: Inconel 625
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 625 is a nonmagnetic, corrosion- and oxidation-resistant, nickel-based alloy. Its outstanding strength and toughness in the temperature range cryogenic to 2000°F (1093°C) are derived primarily from the solid solution effects of the refractory metals, columbium and molybdenum, in a nickel-chromium matrix. The alloy has excellent fatigue strength and stress-corrosion cracking resistance to chloride ions.
nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Alloy 625 has withstood many corrosive environments. In alkaline, salt water, fresh water, neutral salts, and in the air, almost no attack occurs. The nickel and chromium provide resistance to oxidizing environments. Nickel and molybdenum provide for resistance to nonoxidizing atmospheres. Pitting and crevice corrosion are prevented by molybdenum.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hot working may be done at 2100°F (1149°C) maximum furnace temperature. Cold forming is possible using standard methods. Use low cutting speeds and sulfur-based cutting fluid for machining.
nickelAlloys.applications: Applications include chemical processing, aerospace, marine engineering, nuclear reactors, and heat exchangers.

nickelAlloys.name: Inconel 800/800H/800HT
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 800/800H/800HT is an iron-nickel-chromium alloy with moderate strength and excellent resistance to oxidation and carburization at high temperatures. It is used in high-temperature petrochemical equipment, resisting sigma phase embrittlement and chloride stress-corrosion cracking. The 800H variant is solution heat-treated for better creep and rupture strength between 1100°F (593°C) and 1800°F (982°C).
applications: Extruded tubing for ethylene and steam methane reforming furnaces

sizesAvailable.Pipes: ¼”NB to 8”NB x SCH 10/40/80/160/XXS (Larger sizes available on request)
sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: The alloy resists oxidation, carburization, and chloride stress-corrosion cracking at high temperatures without forming the embrittling sigma phase.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hot working between 1600°F–2200°F (870°C–1205°C). Cold forming with standard methods. Annealing may be required to restore ductility.

nickelAlloys.name: Inconel 625LCF
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 625LCF is a nonmagnetic, corrosion- and oxidation-resistant, nickel-based alloy. It was developed as a bellows quality version of Alloy 625 and offers superior fatigue resistance. Its outstanding strength and toughness in the temperature range cryogenic to 2000°F (1093°C) are derived primarily from the solid solution effects of columbium and molybdenum in a nickel-chromium matrix. The alloy has excellent fatigue strength and stress-corrosion cracking resistance to chloride ions. Typical applications include heat shields, furnace hardware, gas turbine engine ducting, combustion liners and spray bars, chemical plant hardware, and special seawater applications.
nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Alloy 625 has withstood many corrosive environments. In alkaline, salt water, fresh water, neutral salts, and air, almost no attack occurs. Nickel and chromium provide resistance to oxidizing environments. Nickel and molybdenum provide resistance to nonoxidizing atmospheres. Pitting and crevice corrosion are prevented by molybdenum. Niobium stabilizes the alloy against sensitization during welding. Chloride stress-corrosion cracking resistance is excellent. The alloy resists scaling and oxidation at high temperatures.
nickelAlloys.pickling: Sodium hydride baths are necessary to descale this alloy. After the sodium hydride treatment, immerse in a sulfuric acid bath at 165°F (74°C) for about 3 minutes. Then immerse in a nitric-hydrofluoric bath at 145°F (63°C) for 25 minutes. Rinse thoroughly. Sulfuric solution: 16% H2SO4 by weight. Nitric solution: 8% HNO3 by weight and 3% HF by weight. For macro-inspection, expose electrolytically to a 3:1 HCl to HNO3 solution saturated with CuCl2 at 0.645 amp/in² (25.4 A/m).
nickelAlloys.workability: Hot working may be done at a maximum furnace temperature of 2100°F (1149°C). Avoid frictional heat build-up to prevent overheating beyond 2100°F (1149°C). Alloy 625 becomes very stiff below 1850°F (1010°C); reheat as needed. Uniform reductions of about 15-20% are recommended to avoid duplex grain structures. Alloy 625 can be cold formed by standard methods. If the material becomes too stiff from cold working, restore ductility by process annealing. Low cutting speeds, rigid tools and setups, heavy equipment, ample coolant, and positive feeds are recommended.

tables.title: Average Hardness and Tensile Data, Room Temperature
High-Speed Cutting Tools for Lathe Turning Operations

nickelAlloys.name: Monel 400
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 400 is a nickel-copper solid solution strengthened alloy with moderate strength, good weldability, good general corrosion resistance and toughness up to 1000°F (538°C). It is resistant to rapidly flowing brackish or seawater, hydrochloric and hydrofluoric acids when de-aerated, and is slightly magnetic at room temperature.

specifications.plate: AMS 4544, ASTM-B-127, ASME-SB-127, QQ-N-281D CL A FM6 AMD 2
specifications.sheet: AMS 4544, ASTM-B-127, ASME-SB-127, QQ-N-281D CL A FM4 AMD 2

sizesAvailable.Pipes: ¼”NB to 8”NB x SCH 10/40/80/160/XXS (Larger sizes available on request)
sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Alloy 400 is virtually immune to chloride ion stress corrosion cracking in typical environments. It is very resistant in reducing environments but poor in oxidizing conditions. Resistant to most alkalis, salts, waters, food products, organic substances and atmospheres at normal and elevated temperatures. Not useful in highly oxidizing acids like nitric/nitrous but resists sulfuric acid up to 80% and hydrochloric acid up to 20%.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hot Working/Cold Working: Readily hot or cold worked. Hot working range is 1700°F to 2150°F with optimum around 2000°F. Finished fabrications can be controlled by amount of hot/cold work and thermal treatments. Machinability: Can be machined with standard tools; cold drawn or cold drawn-stress relieved material is best for machinability and finish. Joining: Can be welded, brazed or soldered with gas or electric welding; neutral flame for gas welding, rapid work without rewelding.
nickelAlloys.heatTreatment: Cold worked and hot worked Alloy 400 can be annealed or stress relieved for desired strength and ductility and to minimize distortion. Annealing: Heat in sulfur-free reducing atmosphere, range 1300°F to 1800°F (most typical 1600–1800°F). Lower temps 1300–1500°F for longer times to minimize grain coarsening. Stress Relieving: Heats to 1000–1050°F for 1–2 hours will relieve strains without recrystallizing the grain structure.

nickelAlloys.name: Monel K500
nickelAlloys.description: Monel nickel-copper alloy K-500 combines the excellent corrosion resistance of Monel 400 with greater strength and hardness through aluminum and titanium additions and controlled age hardening.

sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.corrosionResistance: Corrosion resistance of Monel K-500 is similar to Monel 400 but with a higher tendency for stress-corrosion cracking when age-hardened. It resists sour-gas environments and high-velocity seawater, making it suitable for marine shafts.

nickelAlloys.name: Hastelloy X
nickelAlloys.description: Hastelloy X is recommended especially for use in furnace applications because it has unusual resistance to oxidizing, reducing, and neutral atmospheres. Furnace rolls made of this alloy were still in good condition after operating for 8,700 hours at 2150 °F (1177°C). Alloy X also has performed well in jet engine tailpipes, afterburner components, cabin heaters, and other aircraft parts.

sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.oxidationResistance: Hastelloy X is a nickel base alloy that possesses exceptional strength and oxidation resistance up to 2200°F. It has also been found to be exceptionally resistant to stress-corrosion cracking in petrochemical applications. The alloy has excellent forming and welding characteristics.
nickelAlloys.workability: Hastelloy X can be forged and, because of its good ductility, can be cold-worked. It can be welded by both manual and automatic welding methods including shielded metal-arc (coated electrodes), gas tungsten-arc (TIG), and gas metal-arc (MIG). Alloy X can also be resistance-welded.
nickelAlloys.machinability: Low cutting speeds, rigid tools and work piece, heavy equipment, ample coolant and positive feeds are general recommendations.

tables.title: High-Speed Cutting Tools for Lathe Turning Operations

nickelAlloys.name: Alloy 263
nickelAlloys.description: Alloy 263 is an age-hardenable Nickel/Cobalt/Chromium/Molybdenum alloy designed to have very good aged strength properties, with excellent fabrication characteristics when supplied in the annealed condition. The alloy is primarily used for applications up to 1650°F (900°C). This material is typically supplied in the annealed condition, and is aged by the customer as part of the fabrication process.

sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1.6mm DIA to 254mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

nickelAlloys.name: Hastelloy B2 & B3
applications: Superior resistance to hydrochloric acid, aluminum chloride catalysts, and other strongly reducing chemicals.
Excellent high-temperature strength in inert and vacuum atmospheres.
Applications in the chemical process industry involving sulfuric, phosphoric, hydrochloric, and acetic acid.
Temperature uses vary from ambient temperature to 1500°F depending on the environments.
nickelAlloys.description: Hastelloy B2/B3 are nickel-molybdenum alloys offering outstanding resistance to strong reducing environments including hydrochloric, sulfuric, acetic, and phosphoric acids. Hastelloy B2 provides excellent resistance to pure sulfuric acid and many non-oxidizing acids while minimizing grain boundary carbide precipitation for enhanced weldability. Hastelloy B3 builds on B2 with improved thermal stability and exceptional resistance to pitting, corrosion, and stress-corrosion cracking. It resists knife-line and heat-affected zone attack and maintains ductility during thermal exposures.

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 304 & 304L
stainlessSteel.description: Stainless steel grades 304 and 304L—also known by their European equivalents 1.4301 and 1.4307—are among the most widely used stainless steels globally. Grade 304 is sometimes referred to by its traditional designation "18/8", indicating its composition of approximately 18% chromium and 8% nickel. This austenitic stainless steel is renowned for its versatility, excellent formability, and deep draw capability, making it ideal for products such as sinks and cookware. Grade 304L is the low carbon version of 304, designed to improve weldability, especially in thick sections. In many cases, material is available in a “dual certified” form that meets both 304 and 304L standards. For high-temperature applications, grade 304H with higher carbon content is also available.
stainlessSteel.corrosionResistance: Stainless steel 304 offers excellent corrosion resistance in a wide range of environments. However, in chloride-rich conditions, pitting and crevice corrosion may occur. Stress corrosion cracking can be a concern at temperatures above 60°C.
applications: Industrial: pharmaceutical, food, dairy & brewery equipment

sizesAvailable.Sheets/Plates: 0.1mm to 100mm Thickness (Larger sizes available on request)
sizesAvailable.Round Bars/Wires: 1mm DIA to 400mm DIA (Larger sizes available on request)

fabricationGuidelines: Use tools exclusively for stainless steel to avoid contamination.
Maintain sharp tools to avoid work hardening and surface damage.
stainlessSteel.coldWorking: Grade 304 work hardens quickly. Cold forming processes may require intermediate annealing to avoid tearing or cracking. A final annealing step is recommended to relieve internal stress and enhance corrosion resistance..
stainlessSteel.hotWorking: Hot forming should be done after heating uniformly to 1149–1260°C.
stainlessSteel.heatTreatment: Annealing possible by heating to 1010–1120°C followed by rapid cooling.
weldability: 304 and 304L are excellent for fusion welding.

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 316 & 316L
stainlessSteel.description: Type 316/316L is a chromium nickel austenitic stainless steel containing molybdenum. The molybdenum addition enhances the corrosion resistance over that of 304/304L in halide environments as well as in reducing acids such as sulfuric and phosphoric acid. Type 316L can be dual certified as 316 when the composition meets the lower carbon limit of 316L and the slightly higher strength levels of 316. Type 316L should be specified for welded applications as the low carbon version eliminates chromium carbide precipitation and enhances the corrosion resistance in the as-welded condition. Type 316/316L resists atmospheric corrosion as well as in moderately oxidizing environments. It also resists corrosion in marine atmospheres and has excellent resistance to intergranular corrosion in the as-welded condition. Type 316/316L has excellent strength and toughness at cryogenic temperatures. Type 316/316L is non-magnetic in the annealed condition but may become slightly magnetic as a result of severe cold working.

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 310 & 310S
stainlessSteel.description: Stainless steel 310/310S is an austenitic heat resistant alloy with excellent resistance to oxidation under mildly cyclic conditions through 2000°F. Its high chromium and nickel contents provide comparable corrosion resistance, superior resistance to oxidation and the retention of a larger fraction of room temperature strength than the common austenitic alloys like Type 304. Stainless 310 is often used at cryogenic temperatures, with excellent toughness to -450°F, and low magnetic permeability.
characteristics: Oxidation resistance to 2000°F
Moderate strength at high temperature
Resistance to hot corrosion
Strength and toughness at cryogenic temperatures
applications: Tube hangers for petroleum refining and steam boilers
Furnace parts, conveyor belts, rollers, oven linings, fans
stainlessSteel.fabricationGuidelines: Type 310/310S is readily fabricated by standard commercial procedures. In comparison to carbon steel, stainless steels are tougher and tend to work harden rapidly. Type 310/310S can be welded using all of the common welding processes.

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 347 & 347H
stainlessSteel.description: Alloy 347 (UNS S34700) is columbium stabilized austenitic stainless steel plate with good general corrosion resistance and somewhat better resistance in strong oxidizing conditions than 321 (UNS S32100). It has excellent resistance to intergranular corrosion after exposure to temperatures in the chromium carbide precipitation range of 800–1500°F (427–816°C). The alloy has good oxidation resistance and creep strength to 1500°F (816°C). It also possesses good low temperature toughness. Alloy 347H (UNS S3409) stainless steel plate is the higher carbon (0.04–0.10) version of the alloy. It was developed for enhanced creep resistance and for higher strength at temperatures above 1000°F (537°C). In most instances, the carbon content of the plate enables dual certification. Alloy 347 stainless steel plate cannot be hardened by heat treatment, only by cold working. It can be easily welded and processed by standard shop fabrication practices.
stainlessSteel.corrosionResistance: Alloy 347 stainless steel plate exhibits good general corrosion resistance that is comparable to 304. It was developed for use in the chromium carbide precipitation range of 800–1500°F (427–816°C) where un-stabilized alloys such as 304 are subject to intergranular attack. In this temperature range, the overall corrosion resistance of Alloy 347 stainless steel plate is superior to Alloy 321 stainless steel plate. Alloy 347 also performs somewhat better than Alloy 321 in strongly oxidizing environments up to 1500°F (816°C). The alloy can be used in nitric solutions, most diluted organic acids at moderate temperatures and in pure phosphoric acid at lower temperatures and up to 10% diluted solutions at elevated temperatures. Alloy 347 stainless steel plate resists polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking in hydrocarbon service. It can also be utilized in chloride or fluoride free caustic solutions at moderate temperatures. Alloy 347 stainless steel plate does not perform well in chloride solutions, even in small concentrations, or in sulfuric acid.
applications: Petroleum Refining – fluid catalytic cracking units, polythionic acid service

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 317L
stainlessSteel.description: Alloy 317L is a low-carbon, high molybdenum austenitic stainless steel with a higher nickel alloy content than 316L. Developed to resist the attack of sulfuric acid compounds, this alloy combines good corrosion resistance with excellent mechanical properties and ease of fabrication. These alloys are frequently used for flue gas desulfurization services in fossil-fuel power plants. Compared to other austenitic stainless steels, 317L offers a higher creep strength, stress to rupture, and tensile strength at elevated temperatures.
features: Produces stronger welds due to lower carbon content
Resists the attack of sulfuric acid compounds
characteristics: Good corrosion resistance
Good mechanical properties
Ease of fabrication
Produces stronger welds due to lower carbon content
Resists the attack of sulfuric acid compounds
applications: Flue gas desulfurization systems found in fossil fuel plants

stainlessSteel.name: Stainless Steel 321 / 321H
stainlessSteel.description: Alloy 321 (UNS S32100) is a titanium stabilized austenitic stainless steel plate with good general corrosion resistance. It has excellent resistance to intergranular corrosion after exposure to temperatures in the chromium carbide precipitation range of 800 – 1500°F (427 – 816°C). The alloy resists oxidation to 1500°F (816°C) and has higher creep and stress rupture properties than alloys 304 and 304L. It also possesses good low temperature toughness. Alloy 321H (UNS S32109) is the higher carbon version of the alloy, developed for enhanced creep resistance and higher strength at temperatures above 1000°F (537°C). The alloy cannot be hardened by heat treatment, only by cold working, and can be easily welded and fabricated by standard shop practices.

fabricationGuidelines.General: Alloy 321 stainless steel plate can be easily welded and processed by standard shop fabrication practices.
fabricationGuidelines.Cold Forming: The alloy is quite ductile and forms easily.
fabricationGuidelines.Hot Forming: Alloy 321 is not suitable for work at temperatures below 1700°F (927°C). This material must be water quenched or fully annealed after working to reattain maximum corrosion resistance.
fabricationGuidelines.Machining: The cold work hardening rate of 321 stainless steel plate makes it less machinable than 410 stainless steel, but similar to 304.

stainlessSteel.corrosionResistance: Alloy 321 stainless steel plate exhibits good general corrosion resistance that is comparable to 304. It was developed for use in the chromium carbide precipitation range of 800 – 1500°F (427 – 816°C) where unstabilized alloys such as 304 are subject to intergranular attack. It can be used in most diluted organic acids at moderate temperatures and in pure phosphoric acid at lower temperatures and up to 10% diluted solutions at elevated temperatures. Alloy 321 resists polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking in hydrocarbon service and can also be used in chloride or fluoride free caustic solutions at moderate temperatures, but it does not perform well in chloride solutions or sulfuric acid service.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Waspaloy
aerospaceAlloys.description: Waspaloy is a precipitation hardening, nickel-based alloy used in elevated temperature applications for gas turbine engine parts requiring high strength and corrosion resistance up to 1600°F (871°C).
aerospaceAlloys.corrosionResistance: Waspaloy has excellent resistance to corrosion by combustion products found in gas turbines and aircraft jet engines at temperatures up to 1600°F. Intergranular oxidation occurs above 1600°F.
aerospaceAlloys.heatTreatment: Annealing: Solution temperature for gamma prime is normally 1860–1880°F. Rapid cooling yields low hardness. Hardening: Best stress rupture and creep properties are generally obtained by high temperature solution treatments, 1900–1975°F. Aging: Stabilize at 1550°F 4–24 hrs, air cool, then precipitation age at 1400°F 16 hrs, air cool.

workability.hotWorking: Hot working range: 1850–2150°F. Recommended furnace temperature: 2150°F. Avoid exceeding recommended temperatures to prevent hot short tears.
workability.coldWorking: Reasonably good cold ductility when annealed. Alloy work hardens rapidly; frequent anneals are needed. Cold-worked parts should not be aged due to strain-age cracking risk.

aerospaceAlloys.machinability: Difficult to machine in any condition. Solution treated is best. Use rigid machines and cemented carbide tools. Maintain positive cuts to avoid glazing and work hardening.
aerospaceAlloys.weldability: Welding should be done in annealed or solution treated condition. Surfaces must be clean. Protect molten weld metal with argon shielding. Re-solution treat welded parts and heat rapidly through aging temperatures.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Kovar Alloy
aerospaceAlloys.description: Kovar alloy is a vacuum melted, iron-nickel-cobalt, low expansion alloy whose chemical composition is controlled within narrow limits to assure precise uniform thermal expansion properties. Extensive quality controls are employed in the manufacture of this alloy to ensure uniform physical and mechanical properties for ease in deep drawing, stamping and machining.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Kovar alloy has been used for making hermetic seals with the harder Pyrex glasses and ceramic materials. This alloy has found wide application in power tubes, microwave tubes, transistors and diodes. In integrated circuits, it has been used for the flat pack and the dual-in-line package.

data.details: Parts should be degassed and annealed in wet hydrogen atmosphere to prevent carbon pickup. Heat within 1540–2010°F for 20 minutes to 2 hours, then cool below 570°F before removal.
A thin, tightly adhering oxide film is formed by heating to 1200–1290°F in air until a dark gray to slight brown oxide appears.

data.recommendation: Heat quickly, avoid soaking. Forge at 2000–2150°F to prevent sulfur pickup and oxide issues.
Use Cool Tool with fatty esters to reduce friction and remove cutting heat.
Use high-speed steel or carbide tooling such as T-15, M-3 Type 2, K-6, #370 Carboloy; ensure tools are sharp and edges are smooth.
Follow specific angles: end cutting 7°, nose radius ~0.005", side cutting 15°, back rake 8°, side rake 8°. Use appropriate feeds/speeds.
Use short drills with thin webs; speeds about 40 FPM, feeds 0.002–0.005" per rev. Reaming: half drill speed, triple feed.
Use slightly larger tap drills; two or three fluted taps; nitrided tools recommended; speed ~20 FPM.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Greek Ascoloy (418)
aerospaceAlloys.description: Greek Ascoloy (418) is a hardenable chromium-nickel-tungsten martensitic alloy that is designed for services at temperatures up to 1200 °F in highly stressed parts. This steel is an extremely deep-hardening grade and is used where slightly superior creep strength and resistance to tempering and stress-corrosion cracking are desired in addition to the general properties of the 12% chromium stainless steels. Typical applications are steam turbine buckets and blades as well as compressor parts in gas turbines and high temperature bolts.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Greek Ascoloy has good resistance to scaling and oxidation at temperatures up to 1400 °F. It resists atmospheric corrosion, weak organic acids and oxidizing acids. It has best corrosion resistance in the hardened and tempered condition.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Custom 455 Stainless
aerospaceAlloys.description: Recognizing the need for high-strength alloys with good corrosion resistance to atmospheric environments, Custom 455 is a martensitic age-hardenable stainless steel. This alloy is relatively soft and formable in the annealed condition. A single-step aging treatment develops exceptionally high yield strength with good ductility and toughness. It can be machined in the annealed condition, welded similarly to other precipitation hardenable stainless steels, and extensively cold formed due to its low work-hardening rate. Dimensional change during hardening is minimal, allowing close-tolerance finish machining in the annealed state.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Custom 455 stainless represents a significant advancement in precipitation hardening stainless steels and should be considered where simple heat treatment, ease of fabrication, high strength and corrosion resistance are required. It resists staining in normal air atmospheres and shows good resistance to pitting, rusting, and stress corrosion cracking. It can be used at elevated temperatures up to 1100 °F for oxidation resistance.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Invar 36
aerospaceAlloys.description: Invar 36 is a 36% nickel-iron alloy possessing a rate of thermal expansion approximately one-tenth that of carbon steel at temperatures up to 400°F (204°C). It is ideal for applications where dimensional stability with temperature variation must be minimized, such as in precision instruments, optical systems, electronic devices, and aerospace assemblies.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Used in radio and electronic devices, aircraft controls, optical and laser systems, bimetallic thermostats, and rod and tube assemblies for temperature regulators.

data.property: Temperature Coefficient of Electrical Resistivity per °F (70–212°F)
Temperature Coefficient of Electrical Resistivity per °C (21–100°C)

data.details: Heat quickly to 2000–2150°F; avoid long soaking to prevent surface checks or sulfur pickup.
Use Cool Tool coolant to control heat buildup, reduce friction, and prevent warpage.
Use T-15, M-3 Type 2, or recommended carbide tools; maintain tool edges in excellent condition.

data.specs: Feed ~0.010–0.012" per rev, 35 FPM; End angle ~7°, Nose radius ~0.005", Side angle ~15°, Back rake ~8°, Side rake ~8°.
Feed ~0.001" per rev, large tip angle >25°, front clearance ~7°.
Avoid overheating; use Invarod filler rod as required.
40 FPM; 3/16" feed ~0.002–0.0025" per rev, 1/2" feed ~0.004–0.005" per rev; use short drills, point angle 118°–120°.
Half drill speed; feed 3× drill feed; margin 0.005–0.010", chamfer 0.005–0.010" at 30°.
Use tap drill slightly larger than standard; face hook 8°–10°; speed ~20 FPM.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Rene 41
aerospaceAlloys.description: Rene 41 is a precipitation hardening, nickel-based high temperature alloy possessing high strength in the 1200–1800°F (649–982°C) range. It is designed for severely stressed high temperature applications such as jet engine and high speed airframe parts.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Used for afterburner parts, turbine casings, wheels, buckets, bolts, and fasteners in jet engines and high-speed airframes.
aerospaceAlloys.corrosionResistance: Highly corrosion and oxidation resistant. Provides excellent resistance to jet engine combustion gases up to 1800°F (982°C).

data.details: Quench from above gamma prime solvus (1950°F/1066°C) for lowest hardness. Hardness: Rockwell B 98/C 30.
Gamma prime solvus: 1960–1980°F (1071–1082°C). Fine grain: 1900–1925°F (1038–1052°C), hold 4 hrs, air cool.
Above solvus: 1975°F (1080°C), hold 1 hr, air cool.
1400°F (760°C) for 16 hrs, air cool. Final hardness Rockwell C 40–45.
Best forged between 2100°F (1149°C) and finishing at 1850–1900°F (1010–1038°C).
Rapid work hardening; frequent annealing required. Avoid strain age cracking by heating quickly through aging range.
Difficult to machine. Use tungsten carbide tools. Typical tool geometry: 0° back rake, 6° side rake, 7° clearance, 10° end cutting edge, 45° side cutting edge, 1/16" nose radius.
Feed: 0.005–0.011"/rev, Depth of cut: 1/32–1/8", Speed: 30–60 FPM. Fully treated or partially aged gives better finish. Aging causes size contraction (~0.0013" per inch).
Weldable by inert gas-arc. Part should be solution treated before welding. Post-weld: solution treat and optionally age at 1650°F (899°C) for 1 hr before final aging.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy A-286
aerospaceAlloys.description: Alloy A-286 is designed for applications requiring high strength and good corrosion resistance at temperatures up to 1300 °F (704 °C). This alloy offers high ductility in notched sections and has superior notched rupture strength compared to many other commercial alloys with similar high temperature properties. It can be precipitation hardened by heat treatments, ensuring uniform maximum strength.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Used in jet engines, superchargers, turbine wheels and blades, frames, casings, afterburner parts, and fasteners.
aerospaceAlloys.corrosionResistance: Excellent up to 1300 °F (704 °C) against many atmospheres in jet engine service. Oxidation resistance equivalent to Type 310 stainless up to 1800 °F (982 °C).

data.details: Rolled or forged at 1900–2050 °F (1038–1121 °C) with short soak. Do not forge below 1700 °F (927 °C).
Solution treated alloy can be cold drawn and formed; stiffer than Type 316 or 310, work hardens rapidly.
Iron-based high-temp alloys easier to machine than nickel/cobalt grades. Carbide insert tools recommended.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy 330
aerospaceAlloys.description: Alloy 330 is an austenitic, nickel-chromium-iron-silicon alloy with outstanding resistance to oxidation and carburization up to 2200°F (1204°C). Its high nickel and chromium content, enhanced by silicon, gives it excellent resistance to oxidation, carburization, chloride stress corrosion cracking, and sigma phase embrittlement in furnace atmospheres. The alloy also has high strength, excellent ductility, and a low coefficient of thermal expansion.
aerospaceAlloys.principalFeatures: Excellent high-temperature strength, low thermal expansion, good oxidation resistance, and outstanding resistance to carburization up to 2200°F. The high nickel content also provides resistance to chloride stress corrosion cracking.
aerospaceAlloys.fabrication: Alloy 330 can be hot or cold formed using standard austenitic stainless steel and nickel alloy procedures. Cold forming is preferred. For hot working, heat uniformly to 2050–2150°F (1120–1180°C) and finish above 1750°F (950°C), followed by water quenching or rapid cooling. Avoid forming in the low ductility range of 1200–1600°F (650–870°C). Anneal after hot working for optimum grain structure.
aerospaceAlloys.heatTreatment: Alloy 330 cannot be hardened by heat treatment. Only cold working increases strength at room temperature. For maximum creep resistance, anneal at 1870–2050°F (1020–1120°C) and water quench. Rapid air cooling below 800°F (425°C) is also acceptable.
aerospaceAlloys.applications: Commonly used in chemical and petrochemical processing, power generation, and heat treatment. Typical uses include furnace parts, heat-treat components and containers, heat exchangers, petrochemical waste remediation units, and boiler fixtures.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy 350
aerospaceAlloys.description: Alloy 350 is a chromium-nickel-molybdenum stainless steel that can be hardened by martensitic transformation and/or precipitation hardening. It is used for gas turbine compressor components like blades, discs, rotors, and shafts where high strength is required at room and intermediate temperatures. It offers good corrosion resistance and high strength depending on the heat treatment.
aerospaceAlloys.corrosionResistance: Superior to other quench-hardenable martensitic stainless steels. Shows good resistance in ordinary atmospheres and mild chemical environments. Double-aged or equalized conditions may lead to intergranular corrosion due to chromium carbides. Sub-zero cooling treatments improve stress-corrosion resistance. Proper heat treatment and passivation are required for optimum resistance.
aerospaceAlloys.heatTreatment: Anneal at 1850–1950°F (1010–1066°C), cool rapidly. For hardening, sub-zero cooling and tempering (SCT) produces higher strength than double aging (DA). Conditioning by rapid cooling at 1710°F (932°C) is recommended before hardening. SCT involves sub-zero cooling at -100°F (-73°C) for at least 3 hours, then tempering at 850°F or 1000°F (454°C or 538°C). Double aging involves holding at 1350–1400°F (732–760°C) for 3 hours, air cooling, then heating to 825–875°F (440–468°C) for 2–3 hours, air cooling again.

workability.hotWorking: Work from a max temperature of 2150°F (1177°C). Finishing temperature should be 1700–1800°F (927–982°C).
workability.coldWorking: In the annealed condition, Alloy 350 is essentially austenitic with good forming characteristics. Higher work hardening rate compared to AISI 300 series. Heating to 300°F (149°C) or above can minimize work hardening.
workability.machining: Best machined in equalized and over-tempered condition. Typical feeds and speeds: High-speed tools: turning cut-off/form: 45 SFPM at 0.001–0.0015 IPR, drilling 1/4"–3/4": 50 SFPM at 0.004–0.008 IPR, reaming: under 1/2" 60 SFPM at 0.003 IPR, over 1/2" 60 SFPM at 0.008 IPR, tapping: 25 SFPM, milling end-peripheral: 85 SFPM at 0.001–0.004 IPR. Broaching: 10 SFPM, chip load 0.002 in/tooth.

aerospaceAlloys.welding: Can be welded by shielded fusion and resistance processes. Oxyacetylene not recommended. Use fillers matching base metal for strength or E/ER308 for standard strength. Weld joints should avoid stress concentrators. Annealing recommended post-weld for best strength and corrosion resistance. Must be conditioned at 1710°F (932°C) before hardening by sub-zero cooling and tempering.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy 13-8
aerospaceAlloys.description: PH 13-8 Mo stainless is a martensitic precipitation/age-hardening stainless steel capable of high strength and hardness along with good resistance to general corrosion and stress-corrosion cracking. The alloy exhibits good ductility and toughness in both longitudinal and transverse directions, and offers high mechanical properties under severe environmental conditions. It has good fabrication characteristics and can be age-hardened by a single low-temperature treatment. Common applications include valve parts, fittings, fasteners, shafts, landing gear parts, pins, lockwashers, aircraft components, nuclear reactor components, and petrochemical equipment where high strength and resistance to stress-corrosion cracking are needed.
specifications: Plate: AMS 5864, AMS 5629, ASTM-A-564, ASME-SA-564, ASTM-A-693, ASME-SA-693
Bar: AMS 5629, ASTM-A-564, ASME-SA-564 ST0160LB0013, HMS 6-1105, DMS 2100

aerospaceAlloys.name: Haynes 188
aerospaceAlloys.description: Haynes 188 is a cobalt-based alloy with excellent high-temperature strength and oxidation resistance up to 2100°F (1150°C) and good ductility after aging. Its unique oxidation resistance comes from small additions of lanthanum, which improves oxide scale adherence and retards diffusion. Haynes 188 maintains good ductility after long exposures at 1200°F to 1600°F (650°C to 870°C) and exhibits increased strength at cryogenic temperatures.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Inconel 722
aerospaceAlloys.description: Inconel 722 is a nickel-chrome alloy strengthened with titanium and aluminum additions. It was used in the J93 engine for the XB-70 bomber, primarily for frames, casings, flanges, struts, and parts made in combination with Alloy 718 investment castings.

aerospaceAlloys.name: L605 (HS 25)
aerospaceAlloys.description: Haynes 25 is a cobalt-based alloy which combines good formability and excellent high-temperature properties. At 1800°F, Haynes 25 sheet has a 100-hour stress-rupture strength of 7000 psi. The alloy is resistant to oxidation and carburization to 1900°F. Haynes 25 has given good service in many jet engine parts, including turbine blades, combustion chambers, afterburner parts, and turbine rings. The alloy has also been used successfully in a variety of industrial furnace applications, including furnace muffles and liners in critical spots in high-temperature kilns.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy X750
aerospaceAlloys.description: Alloy X-750 is a precipitation-hardenable alloy which has been used in applications such as high temperature structural members for gas turbines, jet engine parts, nuclear power plant applications, heat-treating fixtures, forming tools, and extrusion dies. The alloy is highly resistant to chemical corrosion and oxidation and has high stress-rupture strength and low creep rates under high stresses at temperatures up to 1500°F (816°C) after suitable heat treatment.

plate: MIL-N-7786C AM2 CHEM & CAP AGED MECH
sheet: MIL-N-7786C AM2 CHEM & CAP AGED MECH

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy 925
aerospaceAlloys.description: This family of alloys includes Alloy 925, Alloy 926, and INCOLOY® Alloy 945 — all designed for exceptional strength, corrosion resistance, and performance in harsh environments such as offshore oil and gas production, sour wells, and chemical processing.

data.description: Alloy 925 (Incoloy 925) is a precipitation-hardenable Nickel-Iron-Chromium alloy with Molybdenum, Copper, Titanium, and Aluminium. Supplied solution annealed and aged. Titanium and Aluminium form Ni3(Al, Ti) gamma prime precipitates during ageing, increasing hardness and strength like Alloys K500, 718, 725. Excellent corrosion resistance comparable to Alloy 825. Nickel protects against stress corrosion cracking; molybdenum and copper resist reducing environments; chromium resists oxidising conditions. PREN above 26 for pitting and crevice corrosion. Used for down-hole sour gas wells and chloride/sulphide environments.
data.applications: Down-hole sour gas wells; General environments where resistance to pitting, crevice, and stress corrosion cracking is required

data.description: Alloy 926 is a high-alloy austenitic stainless steel with elevated molybdenum, providing excellent general corrosion resistance plus improved resistance to pitting, crevice corrosion, and chloride-induced stress corrosion cracking vs standard austenitic stainless steels. Good performance in oxidising and reducing conditions.
data.applications: Vaporizers, heat exchangers, tank housings in phosphoric acid production; Facilities and pipework for diluted sulfuric/phosphoric acid with chlorides; Distributor systems, coolers for sulfuric acid plants; Salt extraction concentration/crystallization plants; Fire extinguishing systems, sea water filtration, offshore hydraulics and injection; Pump frames and lines for oil extraction; Pump lines, couplings, wire lines for oil/gas extraction; Condenser pipes and pipework for power plants with contaminated cooling water; Flue gas desulfurization parts; Bleaching equipment for the pulp industry; Flexible offshore pipes; Tanks for aggressive chemicals

data.description: INCOLOY® Alloy 945 is a high-strength, corrosion-resistant, age-hardenable Nickel-Iron-Chromium alloy for demanding oil and gas service. Molybdenum, copper, niobium, titanium, and aluminum add strength and corrosion resistance. Nickel protects against chloride-induced stress corrosion cracking; molybdenum and copper resist general corrosion in reducing conditions; molybdenum adds pitting and crevice corrosion resistance; chromium protects in oxidising conditions. Niobium, titanium, and aluminium form gamma prime/double prime precipitates during heat treatment. Approved under NACE MR0175 / ISO 15156-3 for severe sour wells and high H₂S service.
data.applications: Downhole and surface gas-well components in sour wells; Tubular products, valves, hangers, landing nipples, tool joints, packers; Fasteners, pump shafting, high-strength piping systems; Shafting for high-strength critical service

aerospaceAlloys.name: Nimonic® 75
aerospaceAlloys.description: Nimonic® 75 is a Nickel-Chromium alloy with Titanium and Carbon additions, offering good corrosion and heat resistance. First used for turbine blades in the 1940s, it is easily fabricated and welded. Common applications now include gas turbine engines, industrial furnaces, and nuclear engineering. Also known as Nicrofer 7520.

aerospaceAlloys.name: Nimonic® 80A
aerospaceAlloys.description: Nimonic® 80A is a nickel-based alloy with excellent heat resistance, good creep and hot oxidation resistance up to 815°C. Produced using VIM and ESR or VAR remelting, it has high cleanliness and homogeneity for consistent properties. Supplied with full traceability and certification, Nimonic® 80A is used for parts operating at high temperatures and mechanical stresses, including engine valves and aerospace engine components.

data.feature: Largely superseded by Nimonic 90 & Inconel X-750
Still specified for nuclear applications due to low cobalt content

aerospaceAlloys.name: Alloy 602CA
aerospaceAlloys.description: Alloy 602CA (2.4633 / Nicrofer® 6025 HT) is a high carbon chromium-iron-nickel alloy containing microalloy elements including titanium, zirconium, aluminum, and yttrium. It offers outstanding high temperature creep strength, exceptional fatigue resistance in both high and low cycle fatigue modes, and extraordinary oxidation resistance under high temperatures and cyclic conditions.

data.feature: Outstanding resistance to cyclic oxidation up to 2250°F (1232°C)
Resistant to carburizing and nitriding environments
Highly resistant to grain growth in service

data.application: Components for exhaust gas purification catalysts
Reformers in chemical and petrochemical industry

data.filler: Covered electrodes: DIN EN ISO 1412: E Ni 6025

data.dimensions: Plates, sheets, tubes, flanges, forged/die-cut rings, round blanks, elbows, T-fittings, reductions, screws, nuts, washers; custom cut with plasma or water jet; superformats up to 2000 x 6000 mm

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Duplex 2205
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Duplex 2205 is a nitrogen-enhanced duplex stainless steel that combines high strength and excellent corrosion resistance, making it the most widely used duplex grade. Its structure of approximately equal parts ferrite and austenite delivers high stress corrosion cracking resistance, good weldability, and superior resistance to pitting and crevice corrosion compared to common stainless steels.
forms: Fittings: elbows, tees, stub-ends, returns, caps, crosses, reducers, pipe nipples, etc.
Welding Wire and Electrode: AWS ER2209, E2209-16, E2209T-1
characteristics: High resistance to chloride stress corrosion cracking
Resistance to chloride pitting and crevice corrosion
Good general corrosion resistance
Good sulfide stress corrosion resistance
High strength
Good weldability and workability
applications: Chemical process vessels, piping and heat exchangers
Pulp mill digesters, bleach washers, chip pre-steaming vessels
Oil field piping and heat exchangers

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Alloy 32750
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Alloy 32750 is a super duplex stainless steel supplied in the solution annealed condition. Combining the desirable aspects of both austenitic and ferritic grades, it achieves a PREN of >41, providing superior pitting and crevice corrosion resistance. It has high yield strength, good ductility and impact strength, excellent resistance to stress corrosion cracking, and is suitable for working temperatures up to 300°C.
characteristics: Excellent corrosion resistance in a wide variety of corrosive chemicals
Pitting Resistance Equivalent number (PREN) of >41
Outstanding resistance to pitting and crevice corrosion in seawater and other chloride environments
Critical Pitting Temperature exceeding 50°C
High strength compared to austenitic and 22%Cr duplex stainless steels
Excellent ductility and impact strength at both ambient and sub-zero temperatures
High resistance to abrasion, erosion, and cavitation erosion
Excellent resistance to stress corrosion cracking in chloride environments
Listed in NACE MR 0175 for sour service
ASME Approval for Pressure Vessel applications
applications: Process industry components in nitric acid, dioxide, polypropylene & PVC production, caustic evaporators
Marine industry and shipbuilding: propellers, shafts, rudders, shaft seals, pumps, bolts, fasteners, valves, instrumentation
Oil & Gas industry: pumps, valves, pipe, vessels, wellhead equipment, subsea equipment
Pollution control systems: fans and pumps, wet scrubbers, incinerators, flue gas desulphurisation (FGD)
Pulp & paper industry: black liquor heater tubes, digester blow valves, rotary feed valves, I.D. fans, brownstock washers, precipitators, bleaching components
Food Industry applications: sugar cane centrifuges, corn and vegetable processing plants
Agrochemicals production such as fertilisers (based on wet phosphoric acid)
Sewage treatment, seawater cooling, desalination plants

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Alloy 32760
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Alloy 32760, also known as Zeron 100, is a super duplex stainless steel combining the desirable aspects of both austenitic and ferritic grades. Its high chromium, molybdenum, tungsten, and nitrogen content gives it a Pitting Resistance Equivalent Number (PREN) of >40 and a Critical Pitting Temperature exceeding 50°C. It delivers excellent corrosion resistance, superior strength, and outstanding performance in aggressive environments such as marine, oil & gas, and chemical processing applications.
characteristics: Excellent corrosion resistance in a wide variety of corrosive chemicals
Pitting Resistance Equivalent number (PREN) of >40
Outstanding resistance to pitting and crevice corrosion in seawater and other chloride-containing environments
Critical Pitting Temperature exceeding 50°C
High strength compared to austenitic and 22%Cr duplex stainless steels
Excellent ductility and impact strength at both ambient and sub-zero temperatures
High resistance to abrasion, erosion, and cavitation erosion
Excellent resistance to stress corrosion cracking in chloride environments
Listed in NACE MR 0175 for sour service
ASME Approval for Pressure Vessel applications
applications: Process industry components in nitric acid, dioxide, polypropylene & PVC production, caustic evaporators
Marine industry and shipbuilding: propellers, shafts, rudders, shaft seals, pumps, bolts, fasteners, valves, instrumentation
Oil & Gas industry: pumps, valves, pipe, vessels, wellhead equipment, subsea equipment
Pollution control systems: fans and pumps, wet scrubbers, incinerators, flue gas desulphurisation (FGD)
Pulp & paper industry: black liquor heater tubes, digester blow valves, rotary feed valves, I.D. fans, brownstock washers, precipitators, bleaching components
Food Industry applications: sugar cane centrifuges, corn and vegetable processing plants
Agrochemicals production such as fertilisers (based on wet phosphoric acid)
Sewage treatment, seawater cooling, desalination plants

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: FERRALIUM 255
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: FERRALIUM 255 is a super duplex stainless steel offering superior corrosion resistance, high strength-to-weight ratio, excellent abrasion and cavitation resistance, and outstanding resistance to pitting, crevice corrosion, and chloride stress corrosion cracking (SCC). With a higher alloy content than standard stainless steels, FERRALIUM 255 is used in demanding environments like chemical processing, marine, petrochemical, pulp & paper, and pollution control industries.
characteristics: Superior corrosion resistance including pitting and crevice corrosion
Excellent resistance to chloride SCC
High strength-to-weight ratio
High fatigue strength in marine environments
Superior abrasion and cavitation erosion resistance
Good ductility and good fabricability
Yield strength twice that of Alloy 20 and stronger than Duplex 2205
40°C critical pitting temperature (twice that of Alloy 2205)
applications: Chemical, marine, metallurgical, municipal sanitation, plastics, oil & gas, petrochemical and pollution control
Wet phosphoric acid and paper-making equipment
Valves, pumps, shafts, marine deck hardware, rudders, shafting
Replacement for admiralty bronze, nickel alloys, and high-performance Ni-Cr-Mo-F-Cu alloys

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: 17-4 PH
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: 17-4 PH stainless steel is the most widely used precipitation-hardening stainless steel, offering a valuable combination of high strength, excellent corrosion resistance, and good mechanical properties at temperatures up to 600°F (316°C). It provides designers with reliability, ease of fabrication, and cost efficiency for a wide range of demanding applications.
characteristics: Excellent resistance to corrosion, comparable to 304 in many media
High strength and hardness with good toughness
Outstanding mechanical properties up to 600°F (316°C)
Good weldability and fabricability
Effective solution for aerospace, chemical, oil & gas, food processing, and general metalworking applications
applications: Chemical refining and petroleum processing equipment

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: 15-5 PH
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: 15-5 PH stainless steel is a martensitic precipitation-hardening stainless steel with approximately 15% Chromium and 5% Nickel. It offers high strength, high hardness, and excellent corrosion resistance, with better transverse toughness and ductility compared to 17-4 PH. Its mechanical properties remain superior in larger cross-sections, it has good forgeability, weldability, and machinability across various heat treat conditions.
characteristics: High strength and high hardness
Excellent corrosion resistance
Superior transverse toughness and ductility vs 17-4 PH
Better mechanical properties in larger cross-sections
Good forgeability, weldability and machinability

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Nitronic 50
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Nitronic 50® stainless steel (UNS S20910 / XM-19) is a high-performance austenitic stainless steel known for its superior corrosion resistance, high strength, excellent toughness, and outstanding resistance to galling and wear. It combines leading-edge composition and advanced manufacturing to deliver exceptional performance in aggressive and corrosive environments, from subsea to aerospace and petrochemical applications.
characteristics: Exceptional corrosion resistance in chloride-bearing environments
High strength compared to 316L and 300 series
Excellent resistance to pitting, crevice corrosion and stress corrosion cracking
Superior wear and galling resistance
Retains mechanical properties across cryogenic to elevated temperatures
Excellent weldability and formability
applications: Oil & gas completion and downhole tools

data.value: Relatively low; suitable for heat retention or insulation

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Nitronic 60
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Nitronic 60® stainless steel is an all-purpose, fully austenitic stainless steel alloy designed for outstanding wear and galling resistance. Its additions of silicon and manganese create a matrix that inhibits wear and galling, even in the annealed condition. With oxidation resistance comparable to 309 and superior to 304, Nitronic 60® performs reliably at high temperatures up to 1800°F. This alloy combines good corrosion resistance, high strength, and excellent performance in applications prone to galling and fretting.
characteristics: Exceptional wear and galling resistance
Good high-temperature oxidation resistance up to 1800°F
Maintains full austenitic structure after severe cold working
Approximately twice the yield strength of 304 and 316
Better chloride pitting resistance than 316
Excellent fretting resistance
applications: Pin and hanger expansion joints for bridges

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Alloy 254
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Alloy 254 (UNS S31254) is a high alloy austenitic stainless steel with significant additions of molybdenum, nickel, and copper, delivering excellent resistance to pitting and crevice corrosion in chloride-rich environments. It offers nearly twice the strength of standard 3xx series stainless steels while maintaining high ductility and toughness at both elevated and sub-zero temperatures. It is a cost-effective alternative to more expensive nickel and titanium alloys for aggressive service conditions.
characteristics: High Pitting Resistance Equivalent Number (PREN ≥ 42)
Excellent corrosion resistance in seawater and halide environments
High resistance to stress corrosion cracking
Superior crevice corrosion resistance
Good erosion corrosion resistance
Excellent ductility and impact strength at all temperatures
Low magnetic permeability
applications: Heat exchangers, piping, valves, pumps for Oil & Gas
Flue gas desulphurisation systems (FGD) in power generation
Marine and shipbuilding components: piping, pumps, valves, heat exchangers
Water treatment and desalination piping and condensers
Pulp & paper bleaching plant vats, drums, press rolls, and piping

AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.name: Alloy 20
AusteniticStainlessDuplexAlloys.description: Alloy 20 (UNS N08020), also known as Carpenter® 20 or 20Cb-3®, is a nickel-iron-chromium austenitic alloy designed for maximum resistance to acid attack, especially sulfuric acid. It provides outstanding resistance to general corrosion, pitting, and crevice corrosion in chloride and acid environments. Niobium addition stabilizes Alloy 20 against sensitization and intergranular corrosion, making it highly reliable for critical chemical processing.
specifications: ASME SB 463, SB 464, SB 473, SB 366, SA 240
characteristics: Excellent resistance to sulfuric acid
High resistance to chloride stress corrosion cracking
Exceptional general corrosion, pitting and crevice corrosion resistance
Good mechanical properties and fabricability
Stable against carbide precipitation during welding
Excels in hot sulfuric acid environments
applications: Tanks, piping, heat exchangers, pumps and valves
Chemical process piping and reactor vessels

TitaniumAlloys.name: Titanium Grade 1
TitaniumAlloys.description: Commercially Pure Titanium Grade 1 is one of the softest and most ductile grades exhibiting the greatest formability. This unalloyed titanium has excellent corrosion resistance, excellent weldability, and is used in a wide variety of applications, especially in marine and chemical industries with harsh environments. It is also used for anodes for cathodic protection.
applications: Implantable battery cases/shields for CRM and Neurostimulation devices

TitaniumAlloys.name: Titanium Grade 2
TitaniumAlloys.description: Titanium Grade 2 is a commercially pure titanium alloy with excellent corrosion resistance and good ductility. It is the most widely used grade among CP titanium alloys due to its balance of strength, formability, and weldability. Grade 2 is used across industries like aerospace, medical, marine, chemical processing and desalination where weight savings, corrosion resistance, and good mechanical properties are important.

data.details: Performed between 400°F and 600°F
900°F to 1100°F, forced air or slow cooling
1200°F to 1400°F for 6 min to 2 hrs, air cool
MIG or TIG with inert gas shielding; pre/post heat not required

TitaniumAlloys.name: Titanium Grade 5
TitaniumAlloys.description: Ti-6Al-4V (Grade 5) is the most widely used high strength titanium alloy, known for its excellent combination of mechanical strength, corrosion resistance, and good heat treatability. It is classified as an alpha-beta alloy and is used in critical applications in aerospace, offshore, autosport, medical, and power generation industries.

TitaniumAlloys.name: Titanium Grade 7
TitaniumAlloys.description: Titanium Grade 7 is similar to Titanium Grade 2 in mechanical and physical properties but with a small addition of palladium, which significantly increases its corrosion resistance, making it the most corrosion resistant of all titanium alloys. It offers excellent weldability and fabricability, making it suitable for chemical processing and harsh environments.
applications: Pulp and paper bleaching and washing equipment

TitaniumAlloys.name: Titanium Grade 12
TitaniumAlloys.description: Titanium Grade 12 is a titanium alloy similar to Grade 2 and Grade 3 but alloyed with Mo and Ni, which provide excellent corrosion resistance, higher strength, and good weldability. It is often used in chemical processing, power generation, desalination, marine hydrocarbon processing, and mining industries. Due to its higher strength, Grade 12 can be used with thinner wall sections compared to Grades 2 and 7 under the same conditions.

otherMiscellaneousAlloys.name: Carbon Steel
otherMiscellaneousAlloys.description: Carbon steel is a steel with carbon content from about 0.05% up to 2.1% by weight. Higher carbon content increases hardness and strength but reduces ductility and weldability. Carbon steel is versatile, widely used for its good machinability and heat treatment capability, and is an environmentally friendly material due to its recyclability.
properties: High strength and hardness with higher carbon content
Good machinability and weldability at low carbon content
Susceptible to rust without protective coatings
Heat treatable to adjust strength and ductility
Energy-efficient to produce and easily recyclable

data.applications: Car parts, pipes, construction, food cans
Springs, edged tools, high strength wires

data.purpose: Softens high-carbon steels for more formability
Produces soft, ductile steel with coarse pearlite
Relieves stress in cold-worked low-carbon steel
Produces uniform structure, eliminates temp gradient
Improves strength and uniformity with fine pearlite
Adjusts final hardness and ductility after quenching
Hardens surface while maintaining tough core

otherMiscellaneousAlloys.name: Alloy Steel
otherMiscellaneousAlloys.description: Alloy steel is a type of steel composed primarily of iron and carbon, alloyed with other elements like manganese, chromium, nickel, molybdenum, vanadium, copper, and others to enhance its mechanical, chemical, and physical properties. Alloy steels offer superior strength, toughness, corrosion resistance, and heat resistance, making them highly versatile and widely used in construction, machinery, automotive, and tool manufacturing.
applications: Cutting tools, stamping dies, measuring instruments
Special components with unique chemical and physical properties
specifications: High-alloy steel: high content of alloying elements
Low-alloy steel: lower content of alloying elements, widely used
Tool steels: high quality, high hardness and wear resistance
Special alloy steels: unique chemical/physical properties

data.purpose: Improves hardenability, allows slower cooling to reduce cracking
Increases corrosion resistance, hardness, strength, and tempering response
Improves ductility, hardness at high temperatures, machinability, and corrosion resistance
Enhances hardness, abrasion and impact resistance; controls grain growth
Increases toughness, strength, and corrosion resistance
Promotes hardness and strength at high temperatures
Improves hardness, especially at high temperatures

data.description: Contains high levels of alloying elements for special properties
Contains lower levels of alloying elements; widely used for structural applications
Used for machine parts and metal structures, requiring flexibility and strength
High hardness and corrosion resistance; used in cutting tools and dies
Unique chemical/physical properties for demanding applications

otherMiscellaneousAlloys.name: LSAW Pipe
otherMiscellaneousAlloys.description: LSAW Pipe (Longitudinal Submerged Arc-Welding Pipe), also known as SAWL pipe, is made from steel plates that are shaped using a molding machine and then welded using double-sided submerged arc welding. This process provides LSAW pipes with excellent ductility, weld toughness, uniformity, plasticity, and sealing performance. They are especially suitable for large-diameter, thick-walled, high-pressure pipelines for oil, gas, and water transport.
properties: Manufactured in large diameters and thicknesses
specifications: Diameter range: 16" to 60" (406 mm to 1500 mm)
Manufacturing method: Longitudinal submerged arc welding
Also known as: SAWL pipe, JCOE pipe
Meets API specifications for Class 1 and Class 2 pipeline areas

data.features: Longitudinal weld, better mechanical properties, higher strength, superior dimensional accuracy, thicker wall production possible, preferred for high-pressure and critical pipelines.

Spiral weld seam, flexible diameter production from same steel strip, cost-effective for larger diameters, suitable for lower-pressure applications, used in construction, water transport, and non-critical pipelines.

data.details: Longitudinal seam ensures consistent, high-quality welds with minimal defects.
Better performance under high internal pressure and critical conditions.
Straightness and roundness make installation easier.
Meets strict regulatory standards for oil/gas transport in cities and offshore.

otherMiscellaneousAlloys.name: Hardox Steel
otherMiscellaneousAlloys.description: Hardox steel, developed by SSAB of Sweden, is a high-strength wear-resistant steel plate known for its exceptional hardness, toughness, and durability. It is widely used in demanding applications such as mining, construction, recycling, and heavy machinery to significantly extend equipment lifespan and reduce downtime caused by abrasion and impact.
applications: Buckets, tippers, and dump truck bodies
Gears of grinding equipment, breaker and knife teeth
properties: High Brinell hardness throughout the plate thickness
Excellent toughness even at low temperatures
Weight reduction through thinner but stronger sections
Longer life cycle under extreme wear and impact conditions
specifications: Thickness range varies by grade: 3 mm to 130 mm
Brinell hardness range: 310 HBW to 700 HBW
Capable of bending, cutting, welding, and machining
Heat treated through hardening and tempering for superior properties

data.details: Exceptional wear resistance due to high through-thickness hardness.
Combines high hardness with high impact toughness; resistant to plastic deformation under heavy load.
Easily cut, bent, and welded using appropriate methods while retaining wear-resistant properties.
Can be processed by plasma cutting, laser cutting, bending, and machining with care to avoid heat-affected loss of properties.

otherMiscellaneousAlloys.name: Aluminum
otherMiscellaneousAlloys.description: AMS-certified aluminum alloys are high-performance materials developed according to stringent Aerospace Material Specifications (AMS) by SAE. These standards ensure that the aluminum meets precise mechanical, thermal, chemical, and structural requirements for use in demanding aerospace applications and other high-performance industries.
properties: Certified to strict AMS material standards
specifications: Common AMS specifications: AMS 4035, AMS 4037, AMS 4044, AMS 4045, AMS 4050, AMS 4094, AMS 4095, AMS 4096, AMS 4162
Additional QQ-A and ASTM equivalents for sheets, plates, bars, extrusions, and marine grades
Available forms: sheet, plate, bar, rod, wire, tubes, extrusions

tables.title: Common AMS Specifications for Aerospace Aluminum

data.applications: Aircraft wings, fuselage panels, structural repairs

data.properties: Good weldability, high strength at elevated temperatures

data.applications: Marine applications, landing gear, fuselage frames
